quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You don't have a choice. AI is going to disrupt in the most aggressive violent ways. If you're not in it, you're about to get kicked out of all of it.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A blunt, high-urgency framing that pushes teams to treat AI adoption as existential rather than optional.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We were about to hit $0 net new ARR, which means we would've been in negative growth territory.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete metric that illustrates the business trigger for a pivot and how to recognize when the core engine is stalling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I said, we need to become a wartime company. If we don't fight for this, we are dead. I jumped hard on AI, but I also restarted the culture. I rewrote the values designed to be a sharp knife to cut out the parts of the company that I just knew wouldn't be effective.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A methodology for transformation that pairs strategic bets (AI) with cultural/operating-system changes to remove organizational drag.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The way that greatness is created is that you find a CEO who's willing to make brave hard decisions and own the results.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A leadership model emphasizing accountability and decisive tradeoffs as the mechanism for creating outsized outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ultimately like 40%.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A specific example of the scale of team turnover that can accompany a major strategic and cultural reset.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
quotes.text: Currently across the business we benchmark ourselves against all public software companies. There's like 120 something B2B software companies. We're like in the 15th percentile for ARR growth, so we're up there.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete benchmarking approach (against a defined public-company set) that practitioners can copy to gauge growth performance objectively.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
quotes.text: Fin, which is our AI agent, which is the future of the business, the thing that will disrupt the old business. It's growing north of 300%.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A clear example of embracing internal disruption—positioning the new AI product as the future even if it cannibalizes the legacy business.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
quotes.text: It took off really fast like all these other AI companies you hear of the first year, it grew from one to 12 million ARR.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A specific growth data point that helps teams calibrate what “fast” can look like for an AI product in year one.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
quotes.text: We're now in solid mid eight digit ARR growth there, we'll pass 100 million ARR with Fin in less than three quarters.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete near-term milestone and timeline that illustrates the scale and pace possible when an AI product hits strong traction.

quotes.topic_title: Intercom and Fin growth metrics today
quotes.text: we are the biggest by customer count, biggest by revenue, best by performance benchmarks. We win all our head-to-heads and our direct competitor bake-offs. We're rated number one on G2, so I think we're doing pretty well.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A practical set of category-leadership proof points (customers, revenue, benchmarks, bake-offs, reviews) that teams can use to measure competitive position.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
quotes.text: We became what a lot of late stage software companies are today, which is a bit bloated. We lost some energy. Our strategy was diluted and unfocused. We're trying to do all the things for all the people.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concise diagnosis of late-stage failure modes—bloat plus strategic dilution—that practitioners can watch for and actively counter.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
quotes.text: We didn't know what problems we were already solving and for who, and the result was very slow revenue growth in the low single digit percent
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Links unclear customer/problem definition to measurable growth stagnation, reinforcing the need for sharp positioning and focus.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
quotes.text: We had this post COVID sugar rush, which a lot of big companies at that stage did in 2021. Everyone's valuation and revenue was through the roof and that hit a lot of problems in a lot of these companies
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that boom times can mask underlying issues and delay necessary strategic corrections.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
quotes.text: we had five quarters of success of sequential decline in our net new ARR and we were about to hit $0 net new ARR which means we would've in negative growth territory.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete metric-based trigger (net-new ARR trend toward zero) that leaders can use as an early warning sign to force decisive change.

quotes.topic_title: Pre-pivot decline and CEO return context
quotes.text: Actually, I got whacked across the head by this AI thing, but it also ended up being a gift.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Reframes disruptive shocks as catalysts—use external disruption to break inertia and justify bold transformation.

quotes.topic_title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
quotes.text: But we had a number of AI engineers in the company already, and so when GPT 3.5 came out, they said, this is different and it didn't take long for people to start to imagine that this is going to be pretty disruptive to service.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Highlights the practical advantage of having in-house AI talent ready to evaluate and act quickly when a platform shift hits.

quotes.topic_title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
quotes.text: And it started where we imagined that this was going to just wreck everyone selling seats, everyone in the conventional SaaS game.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A disruption lens: assume the new tech can invalidate the incumbent business model, then plan accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
quotes.text: But we were only six weeks into the launch of GPT 3.5 when we actually had a beta version of Fin.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete speed benchmark for turning a breakthrough model release into a working product beta.

quotes.topic_title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
quotes.text: part of what we had to our advantage also was that we had this giant base 300, sorry, 30,000 paying customers, hundreds of thousands of active users, millions of their users, billions of data points.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Specific scale/data advantages that can make AI productization faster and more defensible.

quotes.topic_title: ChatGPT moment and early Fin prototype
quotes.text: but we were coming from a point of having nothing to lose.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive strategic framing: extreme pivots are easier (and sometimes necessary) when the status quo is already untenable.

quotes.topic_title: From anti-bot stance to AI-as-personal
quotes.text: But I'm now of the belief that providing a customer with a highly engaged, instantly available expert, consistent, fast, charismatic, funny, friendly, personal agent available for literally every single customer every minute of the day around the clock is so much more personal than making them wait 2, 3, 4 days for a crappy canned response.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Reframes “personal” support as speed, consistency, and availability—arguing AI can be more personal than delayed human replies.

quotes.topic_title: From anti-bot stance to AI-as-personal
quotes.text: You must be part of it.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A blunt strategic principle for platform shifts: don’t resist inevitable technology waves—adapt and participate.

quotes.topic_title: From anti-bot stance to AI-as-personal
quotes.text: Look at Waymo. So, Waymo doesn't crash. It has 3.5 times less crashes than humans.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Uses a concrete comparative metric to argue AI can outperform humans on safety and reliability in real-world tasks.

quotes.topic_title: From anti-bot stance to AI-as-personal
quotes.text: I'm pro-human, I love humans. I really want humans in the mix for all things in the rest of my life, but when it comes to practical, productive, efficient, and effective value, the glue in between the human parts of our lives, I actually want AI and robotics.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Offers a decision heuristic: reserve humans for “human parts” of life, and use AI/robots for utilitarian connective work.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
quotes.text: when you're trying to do all the things for all the people, your efforts to capture all that different types of value are going to necessitate pretty complex pricing.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Connects unfocused product strategy directly to pricing complexity as an inevitable outcome—useful for diagnosing pricing problems at the root.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
quotes.text: the other part of the problem was an unwillingness to frankly make bold decisions, say no, pick a lane and actually take pain in the short term for the long term.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A clear decision-making principle: simplify by narrowing scope and accepting near-term revenue pain to improve long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
quotes.text: I can't remember how much we wrote down, but we actually have already given away something like $50 million in ARR.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing the scale of revenue they were willing to forgo to fix pricing and rebuild trust.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
quotes.text: when people feel like they have far simpler, more predictable, fairer pricing, they'll stick around longer and it creates so much more ease in the company and promotes a healthier relationship with the customer too.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Actionable retention and operations insight: pricing simplicity can improve churn, internal execution, and customer relationships simultaneously.

quotes.topic_title: Legacy pricing problems and simplifying pricing
quotes.text: When our people saw that we were screwing customers effectively in every direction, it starts to erode the idea that we care about our customers and then they make other customer-unfriendly decisions.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive cultural mechanism: bad pricing doesn’t just hurt customers—it degrades internal norms and cascades into more anti-customer behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
quotes.text: You betray your intuition in little bits and pieces over the years when the bright spark of your original idea turns into this big, unstoppable, scary corporate beast and a little bit of you dies every single time you go and betray yourself in that way.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how incremental compromises erode founder conviction and company vitality over time.

quotes.topic_title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
quotes.text: I made a lot of compromises as a lot of founders and founding CEOs do to placate employees or do it out fear to bring investors along, following advice in the industry and best practices.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that “best practices” and stakeholder-pleasing compromises can dilute execution and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
quotes.text: I decided to take a very authoritarian, top-down, aggressive founder-first approach to all the things, and I found that deeply cathartic
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Actionable leadership shift: when execution is diluted, explicitly centralizing decisions can be a deliberate reset lever.

quotes.topic_title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
quotes.text: Actually, it's a big messy cocktail of things.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Useful reframing that major pivots rarely come from a single “aha” moment, but from multiple overlapping pressures and signals.

quotes.topic_title: Decision to go all-in and founder mode
quotes.text: We saw our revenue growth crater. We were used to nice double digits. We were in low single digits.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Concrete performance signal that triggered urgency—growth deceleration as a forcing function for strategic change.

quotes.topic_title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
quotes.text: I saw a stat that when you first launched, when you first had this kind of prototype, you were losing money on every transaction that you're charging like a dollar, it cost you $120, something like that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete early unit-economics data point showing how extreme negative margins can be during prototyping.

quotes.topic_title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
quotes.text: We charge 99 cents to resolve tickets, customer problems, and we have a higher resolution rate than anyone else, and we are proud of that and we obsess over that.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Ties outcome-based pricing to a single operational metric (resolution rate) that the team can obsess over.

quotes.topic_title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
quotes.text: It is the metric by which these agents are assessed, and we wanted our revenue to be 100% aligned with the value that they attained because we had all this scar tissue from pricing prior that felt unfair to customers.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A value-alignment pricing principle: price on the same outcome you manage internally to build trust and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
quotes.text: We basically said that if someone is not prepared to pay 99 cent for us to rapidly and elegantly perfectly and excellently solve their customer's problem, we need to wrap this up. We don't have a business here.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A hard-nosed willingness-to-pay test that uses pricing as a viability filter, not just a monetization lever.

quotes.topic_title: Fin outcome-based pricing and unit economics
quotes.text: I always believe that that pricing should come from value and not from costs. The cost is our problem.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Memorable pricing mental model: set price by customer value, then force the business to make costs work.

quotes.topic_title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
quotes.text: One was we were burning a lot of money, so I cut a lot of costs aggressively. Canned a bunch of different projects. We had this big glorious office we were about to fit out and I'm like, we're about to hit negative growth territory, stop it.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete example of an immediate operational reset: aggressively cutting spend and stopping non-essential projects when growth turns.

quotes.topic_title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
quotes.text: It was the type of decision that where I had to practice the professional CEO approach, which is, "Hey folks, what do you all think? Let's take everyone's input. Let's put it all down on a spreadsheet." Everyone had color beside all of the different options that we may take. Let's make a group decision. I said, "Sorry, this is what we're doing."
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A contrarian leadership stance: using input-gathering but making a decisive, top-down call to force strategic focus.

quotes.topic_title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
quotes.text: And then I designed these quarterly performance processes where not only would you get a mark or a grade for your performance against your goals that quarter, but you'd also get a score for your behavior against the values.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A practical operating mechanism for culture change: measuring both outcomes and values-aligned behaviors every quarter.

quotes.topic_title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
quotes.text: And I hard coded a formula myself, and so I took it out of the manager's hands to say, if people got below a certain mark, respectfully and lovingly, we would say, thank you for your service. We're going to go forward without you.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A methodology for reducing inconsistency and politics in performance management by using a predefined formula tied to consequences.

quotes.topic_title: Operational reset: costs, focus, culture overhaul
quotes.text: We ran an anonymous employee survey, I think 15 or 16 months after I started aggressively working through the org and rebuilding the org and rebuilding the culture, and we had a 98 to 99% approval of management, leadership and new strategy.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A specific data point showing that a painful, deliberate culture overhaul can result in extremely high alignment and leadership approval.

quotes.topic_title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
quotes.text: And it's my strong belief that great employees and great companies want and are constructed out of a very clear and strong hierarchy where it is the responsibility of the CEO to make brave and hard decisions unilaterally, yes, using their experts as inputs and be responsible for the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A clear operating model for decision-making: expert input, but CEO-owned unilateral calls with full accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
quotes.text: But like I said, there will be friction changing a company that's configured for democracy and committee decisions and soft and gentle interactions and communication to be properly founder led and top down.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A warning that shifting governance/decision style creates predictable resistance—useful for planning change management.

quotes.topic_title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
quotes.text: Could be something ultimately like 40%. So, it was a big, big turnover over some couple number of years.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete data point on the magnitude of talent churn that can accompany a major strategic and cultural reset.

quotes.topic_title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
quotes.text: There's such a thing as product market fit. There's a thing as founder market fit, there's a thing as founder, product market fit. That's how you're doing it right, but there's also such a thing as employee, founder, product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A memorable extension of “fit” thinking into hiring and culture: aligning employees to the founder and mission style.

quotes.topic_title: Soft coup, hierarchy, and 40% turnover
quotes.text: So, even if it requires a little bit of a loving push out the door, I know that you're actually doing them a favor in the medium to long run.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A counterintuitive retention/attrition philosophy: helping misaligned employees exit can improve outcomes for both sides.

quotes.topic_title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
quotes.text: When a founder runs away from their business, it is the ultimate betrayal of their heart and the dream that they have.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A stark mental model for distinguishing a deliberate shutdown from avoidance, and why returning can be emotionally necessary.

quotes.topic_title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
quotes.text: That said, the reality is that for particularly people like me who like the adventure and the high agency being unilateral, day-to-day movement where you're trying to make big, wild, bold decisions, the reality is that if you're successful, most of your days will not be that.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that success often replaces “founder adventure” with operational, managerial work—useful for setting expectations and designing roles.

quotes.topic_title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
quotes.text: It'll be reviewing the bonus policy for next year and reviewing the comp proposal for your execs for the next year.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete example of the unglamorous executive workload that founders should anticipate and plan for as the company scales.

quotes.topic_title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
quotes.text: It'll be rushing from meeting to meeting, having 8, 9, 10 meetings a day. I don't happen to believe that that's a great way to live your life.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A specific data point about meeting load paired with a value judgment that can prompt practitioners to redesign calendars and operating cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Founder emotional journey and corporate reality
quotes.text: You're giving me an opportunity to paint story of this maverick led adventure that you might imagine in a comic. I'm for some reason picturing TinTin sail the seas, this swashbuckling adventure. It's not. It's corporate life kind of sucks particularly for people like me.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that punctures the romantic pivot narrative and highlights the corporate reality founders must be willing to endure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: To thrive in the AI era organizations need to adapt quickly, but many organization leaders struggle to answer pressing questions like which tools are working, how are they being used, what's actually driving value?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames a practical measurement problem leaders can use to guide AI tool adoption and ROI evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: DX provides the data and insights that leaders need to navigate this shift.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the actionable approach of using data/insights (not anecdotes) to manage AI-driven change.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With DX, companies like Dropbox, Booking.com, Adyen and Intercom get a deep understanding of how AI is providing value to their developers and what impact AI is having on engineering productivity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of well-known companies using a system to quantify AI’s impact on developer productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: there's always this talk of agents will do everything and all the SaaS software is going to be replaced by agents.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Captures a provocative, industry-wide claim that challenges conventional assumptions about the future of SaaS.

quotes.topic_title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
quotes.text: Customer experience really is service success, sales and marketing, in my opinion. It's all engagement with all customers. It's the biggest part by headcount of any business.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Reframes “CX” as a broad umbrella (service/success/sales/marketing), helping leaders size the true scope of agent-driven disruption and prioritize where automation will matter most.

quotes.topic_title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
quotes.text: Any function that requires a lot repetitive operational mechanical work will be automated, whether it's chasing or collecting or issuing invoices, it could be onboarding or offboarding employees.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Gives a practical heuristic for identifying which workflows to target first with agents, with concrete examples across finance and HR ops.

quotes.topic_title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
quotes.text: I imagine it as a medley of humans and agents, and I don't think it's obviously going to be humans on the top and the agents all in the IC roles.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Challenges the default org-chart assumption and suggests practitioners should design for mixed human/agent roles rather than a simple “agents replace ICs” model.

quotes.topic_title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
quotes.text: I won't be surprised if there are agents at the highest level too.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Pushes the disruption boundary into executive coordination, prompting leaders to consider agent augmentation even in staff/leadership functions.

quotes.topic_title: How far agents disrupt software and org design
quotes.text: But what I think that all brings is just epic levels of efficiency. It's going to be super deflationary. There'll be a lot more competition.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Connects agent adoption to macro business outcomes (deflation and competition), a useful lens for strategy and pricing decisions as automation spreads.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
quotes.text: Yeah. Well, I don't find it to be particularly touchy because jobs have always gone away and technology has done a really good job at stealing jobs that we're repetitive, demeaning, dangerous.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Reframes the jobs debate with a clear mental model: automation predictably targets repetitive/demeaning/dangerous work first.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
quotes.text: You ask a human to sit at a keyboard answering the same question day in, day out, and you get to a point where you don't even ask them to answer the question manually. You ask them to click the button that brings up the macro. Like what a horrible use of a human life.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A concrete litmus test for automation candidates: if the job devolves into macros/button-clicking, it’s ripe for AI replacement.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
quotes.text: And to get specific, they will be CX roles and a lot of basic repetitive roles. There is a lot of repetitive stuff in sales, and so you'll do more sales with less people.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A practical forecast for workforce planning: expect CX and repetitive sales tasks to shrink, increasing output per remaining headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
quotes.text: But what he's getting at is that what sales people bring to the table is human connection and trust, and that is not about to go away anytime soon.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Defines the durable “moat” for human roles: trust and connection remain valuable even as task work gets automated.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs impact: what disappears and what remains
quotes.text: The abundance of AI is going to make automated things worth zero.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive pricing insight: as AI makes content abundant, differentiation shifts to craft, humanity, and quality that people will pay for.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
quotes.text: I think it's ultimately that you don't have a choice.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A forcing-function mindset for incumbents: treat AI adoption as mandatory, not optional.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
quotes.text: I think AI is bigger than all these things.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A scale comparison mental model that reframes AI as a platform shift larger than prior waves (PC, internet, mobile).

quotes.topic_title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
quotes.text: So my strongest advice is roll your sleeves up, figure out what's going to disrupt you, have fun with it. You need to bring in actual talent. We and I will be nothing if we didn't have actual AI scientists and leaders.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Concrete playbook: proactively identify disruption vectors and hire real AI leadership rather than dabbling.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
quotes.text: And unfortunately, part of what you learn from them is the only way you're going to win right now is if you work your ass off, because all these little AI companies run by kids in their twenties are literally working 12 hours a day, literally 365 days a year.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: A competitive intensity benchmark that explains why AI-native startups can outpace incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for incumbents: no choice, hire talent, work hard
quotes.text: And so my actual advice, which is not that helpful, is that if founders of previous generation companies are themselves not willing to roll up their sleeves and get into it and work as hard as the kids, hire a kid. You can be a chairperson like I was, have a lot of fun. You can mentor the kid, hire a kid because you're in the wrong job, buddy.
quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.context: Counterintuitive succession advice: if you can’t match AI-era pace, empower younger operators who can.
